info.game_comments:
2000-B College Championship quarterfinal game 3.  
From the University of Washington in Seattle.

(1, 1).clue: The 2 slaves Michelangelo sculpted for the unfinished tomb of Pope Julius II are in this Parisian museum

(2, 1).clue: "The Onion" reported that 450,000 unsold copies of "TIME"'s special issue on this April "day" went to a landfill

(3, 1).clue: These 2 "stately" rivers are the longest in the U.S.

(4, 1).clue: "I will not encourage others to fly" & "I will not skateboard in the halls" are 2 of his chalkboard scribblings

(6, 1).clue: In June 2000 this group boosted production by 3% but said high U.S. gas prices aren't its fault

(1, 2).clue: The Sapporo Snow Festival in this country features stunning snow sculptures like the one seen here:

(2, 2).clue: In a headline from history, "War Rationing Boards Restricts Nylon Use to Armed Forces" & this FBI director

(3, 2).clue: Mespotamia, where many early civilizations developed, was located between these 2 rivers

(4, 2).clue: These devices on the undersides of boards hold the wheels & share their name with large transport vehicles

(5, 2).clue: A baked confection for a rattler

(6, 2).clue: Geologists use this earthquake measuring instrument to figure out where to drill for oil

(1, 3).clue: Tutu much!  A bronze ballerina by this artist was auctioned off for $11.9 million in 1996

(2, 3).clue: In entertainment news, Anatoly Ivaskevich hosts this country's hit game show "Who Wants to Eat a Meal?"

(3, 3).clue: This large lake is the chief source of the Nile River

(4, 3).clue: Of Cruiser, Thrasher, or Grinder, the magazine that's the bible of rad skateboard culture

(5, 3).clue: A stinky barn-dwelling bird of prey

(6, 3).clue: Workers on a drilling crew are said to be "rough" in this body part

(1, 4).clue: The colossal figures seen here are found in this country:

(2, 4).clue: Most coverage of this territory's return to China left out its desperate plea to Jackie Chan for help

(3, 4).clue: Less than half the size of the Pacific, it's the third-largest ocean

(4, 4).clue: Stan Laurel could tell you the name of this trick where the board is propelled into the air by tapping the tail hard

(6, 4).clue: This company now better known for motor oil takes its name from the state where petroleum was found in 1859

(1, 5).clue: This Frenchman sculpted Victor Hugo in 1886 & Pope Benedict XV in 1915

(2, 5).clue: It was a sad day when an employee of this computer company was fired for "thinking a little too different"

(3, 5).clue: The Sea of Crete is the southernmost part of this sea, an arm of the Mediterranean

(4, 5).clue: Last name of skateboarding legend Tony, who's never "dove-ish" when bombing or carving

(6, 5).clue: The oilfields that led to a 1920s scandal are named for this feature seen here (note the spout?):

(1, 1).clue: Argentina cried for her when this former actress & first lady died of cancer in 1952

(2, 1).clue: This band's last U.S. concert was at Seattle's Center Arena on January 8, 1994

(3, 1).clue: A real 19th century whale named Mocha Dick may have inspired this 1851 novel

(4, 1).clue: About 2 million in Northwestern Spain speak Galician, a dialect of this language spoken by its neighbor

(5, 1).clue: Zoology:Animals of the genus Rangifer that provide the Lapps with meat, milk, clothing & transportation

(1, 2).clue: Her findings on pesticides in the book "Silent Spring" sparked the environmental protection movement

(2, 2).clue: Born in Washington in 1942, he's the musician heard here:

(3, 2).clue: In 2000 this creator of Augie March & Mr. Sammler gave us "Ravelstein", who resembles scholar Allan Bloom

(4, 2).clue: Cornish, the language of this county of England, became extinct in 1777

(5, 2).clue: Classical Mythology:Oddly, these "heavenly" twins had the same mother, Leda, but different fathers

(6, 2).clue: A chambermaid does it to your pillow; forgetful actors do it to their lines

(1, 3).clue: This 19th century woman boasted, "I never ran my train off the track and I never lost a passenger"

(2, 3).clue: An official Pearl Jam website informs us this singer likes card tricks & the Chicago Bulls

(3, 3).clue: It's said that Doc in his novel "Cannery Row" is based on a marine biologist with whom he'd written a book

(4, 3).clue: With nearly 50 million speakers, this Bantu language is the most widely spoken in Africa

(5, 3).clue: 20th Century Literature:First name of Jack London's sea captain Larson of the Ghost

(6, 3).clue: This 3-letter name of an illness sounds like part of a chimney

(1, 4).clue: King Henry VIII's first wife, Catherine of Aragon, was the daughter of this famous queen

(2, 4).clue: This '90s band named themselves after the Seattle art installation seen here:

(3, 4).clue: Edward Driffield, a novelist in Maugham's "Cakes and Ale", is said to be based on this "Jude the Obscure" author

(4, 4).clue: In 1928 this president of Turkey outlawed Ottoman Turkish & switched alphabets from Arabic to Roman

(5, 4).clue: Math Year 1:As a rule every fraction can be expressed as a terminating decimal or this kind

(6, 4).clue: Provided for a horse's dining pleasure, it's also called a nose bag

(1, 5).clue: Seen here, this woman did quite a "smashing" job during her crusade against liquor:

(2, 5).clue: Robyn Miller composed the music for Myst & this 1997 CD-ROM sequel

(3, 5).clue: "The Financier" by this author of "Sister Carrie" was inspired by real financier Charles T. Yerkes

(4, 5).clue: About 3/4 of Sri Lankans speak Sinhala & about 1/4 speak this as their native language

(5, 5).clue: Religion 1400-1600:This queen had Protestant Thomas Cranmer burned for heresy

(6, 5).clue: It's the kind of sycophantic favor-seeking you'd expect from someone named Bambi

(0, 0).clue: This annual event was co-created in 1993 by Marie C. Wilson, mother of 5 & president of the National Ms. Foundation
